projects.Title: Airships
projects.BodyContent:
One passion of mine since 2010 has been Minecraft. I find it's a neat medium for voxel modeling and leaves some room for the imagination. It's also cheaper than legos. I got to lead a team of like-minded builders making a hub world for a server we played on, and other than learning the ropes of project planning and managing a group of folks, I got to do a bit of concept work as well!

We went with a steampunk theme, and I really liked the idea of building airships! I enjoyed thinking about how an airship might function and how to represent those functions while constrained by Minecraft's palette of blocks. I also did a bit of worldbuilding, thinking about parts that might be standardized by my imaginary manufacturer, WDI, and making ships that were modified to fit different needs. If there's one thing I'm the happiest about, it's that all the layers and spaces bleed into each other vertically. It's not like there just a main level and then a level above or below that, but they just flow nicely and moving through them in-game felt claustrophobic but fluid, which I imagine would fit the constraints of a vessel that needs to keep itself in the air. I've added interactive views of each one below! You can use your mouse to navigate around the models or click on the annotations to view specific areas that I marked, from things like the rudder to the helm!
WDI Archon
The Archon was my first airship design. that I made before working on the build mentioned above, so you could say it was basically my prototype. I designed it as a military/anti-piracy vessel, so the hull's been reinforced with dark brown armor plates and plenty of mounted weapons. Additionally, the hold has been hollowed out to make room for a deployable strike craft ornithopter.

WDI Leviathan
The Leviathan was my second airship, this time designed as a merchant vessel built off of the same frame as the Archon, and I imagine that the Archon was just a militarized version of the Leviathan rather than the other way around. It features a larger hold and landing skids, and felt a lot more open than the Archon's armored walkways.

Penzance's Plunder
The Penzance's Plunder I designed as a pirate vessel, and it's sleeker profile and two large propellers instead of one drive prop and two steering props show that the vessel was designed for speed, what might have once been a racing vessel converted to blockade running. It's been armed but not armored, with a large anti-aircraft gun in the front being its main armament and grappling ballistas being on each side to aid in boarding activities. I also didn't imagine the pirates would be docking it often, so it features a ladder that can drop down for boarding.

WDI Life Boat
The WDI Life Boat was the largest airship I built, and served an actual purpose for the server being a venue for so-called "drop parties" where people would drop free items while the rest of the server ran around on the deck below trying to pick up free and often valuable goodies. With this in mind, I was going for the look of a pleasure craft but building around the large main deck. With that in mind, it has many indoor and outdoor observation decks, with some fully enclosed by glass to help get out of the choppy winds outdoors. For a ship as large as it is, it features extra propulsion with the engines from the Penzance's Plunder being relegated to merely steering propellers. As seemed fitting to a party vessel, the main balloon was instead turned into colorful smaller balloons, not just to resemble party balloons but to have redundancy in case there were to be damage.

WDI Waftsail
In a world with all of these large crewed airships, what would a small commuter airship look like? That's the line of thinking that led me to build the WDI Waftsail. While smaller than the other airships, care was still taken in imagining how it would function. It has a lot of the same "hardware" as its larger companions, just scaled down. I also figured that if there were a bunch of these in production, emphasis would be placed on the colors and patterning of the balloons, buth in order to differentiate them but also because owners would probably want to pick from the colors and patterns to find one they'd enjoy most!
projects.Description: Airships used in a Minecraft Server's hub world

projects.Title: Arches
projects.BodyContent:
Arches were the final result of what was called the Tool Project. We started by being assigned a simple hand tool and we had to become really familiar with it. We drafted it, studied and drew its movement, and imagined how the section cut of the tool would change in the motions of being used. After that , we were paired up with another student and merged our motions to create a form.

My tool was a tortilla press, and my partner's tool was a knife sharpener. The end model had elements reflecting the hinging over time and the heaviness of the tortilla press, but also elements of repetition and cutting from the knife sharpener. The model in its many iterations focused on light and space, with two spaces under a shared roof divided by cutting vertical slats.

The big takeaway from this project was working with another individual on a high-stakes project. While the Building Study project had us working together in a group of three, this project was working on something original, and I think we made the mistake of not playing to each other's strengths. Vincent is a great designer and my specialty is in the fabrication, but I think in trying to find compromise we ended up with something neither of us was too happy with.

That being said, I do appreciate the drawings I made as part of this project, and I also pushed my renders to a higher level than before. On a previous iteration of my portfolio website, I actually used these renders as the header and footer of the website, and I think the renders really leverage the strengths of the architecture.
projects.Description: A pavilion derived from a tortilla press and a knife sharpener

projects.Title: Saco Lake Bathhouse
projects.BodyContent:
This project was a wellness center that included pools for bathing accommodating both shallow and deep water, saunas, an area for yoga and meditation situated near Saco Lake, New Hampshire. The project demanded we be mindful of the interplay between the site and the bathhouse, as well as considering mindfulness and atmosphere.

I envisioned the heavily forested site could have unique play with the trees surrounding it, and could fade into the background by imitating the trees around it. To separate those coming to the bathhouse to utilize its facilities from those who just wanted to hike in and take in the view, I designed the structure to have two concentric staircases, one of which was accessible from the inside of the building while the other was accessible from outside. Hikers could access a lower observation deck while those who went through the changing rooms, baths, and saunas could access a rooftop observation deck, which also maintains the privacy of those utilizing the rooftop for meditation or yoga.

During this project, I tried experimenting with a different method of rendering with overlaid colors and gradients. It was a style I had seen utilized by Studio SHAFT in their Monogatari series for background shots and I liked how they turned out. Instead of focusing too hard on realism, I think they were able to emphasize the atmosphere I was going for. You enter into a dark and cramped space, you bathe in the dark and then enter into verticality, into the light. I also got to utilize digital fabrication, with one of the stairs being 3D printed, the other print unfortunately refusing to cooperate before the deadline. I also chopped my file up for laser cutting to great effect, especially with the site model.

I'm glad that I got to try a lot of new things in the project, and I'm still really happy with the way the site model, building drawings, and renders turned out! While the model itself still left room for improvement, I played an important role in me utilizing digital fabrication technologies more! I only wish tree supports had been common then, and it's surprising that nobody at university taught me about deburring tools until I learned machining.
projects.Description: A bathhouse overlooking Saco Lake

projects.Title: Building Study
projects.BodyContent:
Architecture has been around for a while now, and architecture of the past has a lot to teach us today. In this project, our group was assigned to get really familiar with an architectural precedent. Our group was assigned the Fredensborg Houses by Jorn Utzon. The project involved getting familiar with the buildings, knowing the measurements and ideas behind them, and finally culminated in a scale model of the buildings and site. Since the Fredensborg Houses are a housing project, the three of us focused on three houses on the east end of the site.

As a group we had to construct the site model and each of us made our own model of the house, although each individual made their own set of drafts. I had a lot of fun with the drafts, since it was very satisfying when all the lines intersected perfectly, which took a lot of trust in yourself and in the process. Plus, the heavy-weight Strathmore paper we used wasn't cheap, especially for a student.

However, the part that I found the most enjoyable was making the models. All you had was a cutting mat, an architect's scale, a straight edge metal rule and an Exacto blade, and you had to do all of your measurements twice before committing to the cut and gluing it all together. If I had done this later in architecture school I would have used a laser cutter, but in a way it was great having to learn how to do it by hand!
projects.Description: A study of Jorn Utzon's Fredensborg Houses

My model with the roof removed, relocated for a better view.

projects.Title: Cube House
projects.BodyContent:
The Cube House Project, also known as the Wedding Pavilion design project, was a studio project where we were given a site covered in hedge, and it was up to us to modify the site to fit the program and the cube house itself. One side of the site had a road while the other faced Lake Erie. The program called for a place for the wedding to take place, room for the couple to get ready and then make their way to the stage, a location for a reception, and some parking and bathrooms.

The deliverables for the project had many pieces. We needed sections and a hand-rendered plan fit to a 1/4"=1' scale, as well as a scaled hand-rendered perspective. We also had digital renders, and finally, the scaled wooden model.

The design itself took heavy inspiration from a theatrical stage, and the layout had a counter-clockwise circulation pattern. Spaces were meant to emphasize transition and threshold.


What I really appreciated about this project was that it was the first studio project where we had to heavily engage with the architecture woodshop, and reflecting upon my work, the design itself might not have been all too compelling, but the experience I gained in assembling the site model was monumental! I took care to make sure all of my wooden pieces lined up just right and really put in the time at the woodshop. At that point, I wasn't great at making sure every piece was toleranced correctly, but to make sure everything slot together perfectly I underwent a trial by fire so to speak.

I also got to experiment more with my render settings, and for this project I tried out the Nvidia IRay plugin while most of my peers were still using the school's licensed version of VRay.

Admittedly, the grandest takeaway for this project was the rendered site plan. I framed that thing after the semester ended and it's been hanging above my bed ever since. I don't think I've ever been content with my ability to draw, but I went the extra mile to add in ambient occlusion and render the distinct textures of gravel paths and grass. If anything, it's one of the better projects I use to benchmark myself when I look back at my work years later!
projects.Description: A design for a wedding pavilion on the shores of Lake Erie

projects.Title: Dungeon Crawl
projects.BodyContent:
This was my final Project for Creative Coding and I loved it a whole lot! I ended up going way overboard any my project ended up being almost a thousand lines of code when it was only supposed to be a couple hundred. And yes, I did get a 100 and some points of extra credit for the effort. Before I go too far though, The game is fully playable if you scroll down below this block of text.

Now, onto the project details! One of the things we covered in our class was the idea of a Turtle, an object that would move around by moving forwards, backwards, and rotating, so its motions weren't dependent on the traditional X and Y grid. I already knew that this was perfect for having basic creatures that could move around, but it would also be perfect for something like a Magic Missile that would follow an arcing non-linear path to its target. I also liked fantasy settings, being very involved with my school's Tabletop Roleplaying games club that was mostly Dungeons & Dragons, and I liked dungeon crawling video games like The Binding of Isaac. I decided that would make for a fun challenge, and so this project was born!

To briefly go over the game itself, it’s a dungeon crawler. The player goes into randomly generated rooms with randomly generated enemies which make up floors of random length. As the player progresses through the floors, the average enemy speed and number in a room will gradually increase. Paired with the player’s health that only partially returns when a floor is completed, it’s certain that the player will die. The question then is how far can they make it?

To help me troubleshoot the project, I added in a ‘debug mode’ of sorts. By pressing ‘=’, the player can see a lot of cheaty data, spawn enemies, generate the final room of each floor, and increase how many floors the game thinks the player has cleared. There were a lot of challenges. I wasn’t sure how to do level generation (the system can easily do non-linear levels by generating more doors but linear is easy to play through) and for a while, enemy AI was giving me some problems.

In the end, I’m more than happy with what I made. I enjoy playing it, I enjoyed making it, and I enjoy changing some of the settings to make the game truly ridiculous. Also the visual assets are either made by me or heavily changed free assets

Project Source Code
Controls
Movement - WASD or the Arrow Keys
Cast Magic Missile - Point and click with your mouse

Tips
  • The glow on your staff indicates how much mana you have
  • If you’re shooting slowly, let up on the firing and just let it recharge
  • The magic missiles bank towards where your mouse is when you fire them
  • Aim slightly ahead of enemies for best results

Debug Controls
Toggle Debug Mode - =
Increase Floor Number - SHIFT
Spawn enemy at cursor - E
Make next room the exit - ENTER
projects.Description: A dungeon crawler playable within your browser

Images.Description: The wizard finds the entrance to the next floor
The wizard died and the player views their stats
The wizard casts their most powerful spell, Debug Mode
My initial concept sketch for what the game would look like
My first proof of concept with Debug Mode, which the game ended up being built off of

projects.Title: Grow Center
projects.BodyContent:
Pittsburgh has a lot of empty lots, with rowhouses frequently being broken up by staccato voids, ghosts of the buildings that once stood there. These gaps aren't dissimilar to the neighborhoods in Pittsburgh, with neighborhoods that share a border realistically taking a half hour or more to reach with the natural borders of cliffsides or the artificial boarders of busways. Our site was 7539 Susquehanna St in Pittsburgh which was a vacant lot in a food desert and the community had set up the Sankofa Village Community Garden. The goal of the Grow Center project was to develop the site and make a resource for the community.

I was interested in using the rowhouse as a unit, so I started by arraying and twisting that unit to get the overall form. The main greenhouse was just one of many spaces available for planting, and was optimized both for sunlight direction but also to be an eyecatcher on the corner of the lot to encourage visitors to engage with the grow center.

I really enjoyed getting to go out to the site, planning sustainable building systems, and researching the climate factors such as sun direction and temperatures and having to relate those to areas for growing plants. I also had my first experience with VR for this project, with my Google Cardboard from the Medieval Fantasy challenge arriving the morning of final review allowing the reviewers to experience some of the main spaces of the building in VR. I also made a flythrough gif of the space, although in hindsight the quality is pretty lacking but that's a product of my laptop at the time and the length it'd take to render individual frames. I was really satisfied with my model, and while it was small, I think it was a great representation of the building. My favorite detail, other than the wire trees, is that the doors in the back of the workshop could open and close on the model, but the one that was painted ended up getting stuck.
projects.Description: A community resource for growing and teaching

projects.Title: Hoop House
projects.BodyContent:
The Hoop House was the second stage of the Fall '17 semester, following the hanging garden project and preceding the Grow Center project. The hoop house was thinking at the scale of a greenhouse, which needed to provide life support for plants over the harsh Pittsburgh winter. Our group consisted of six members of diverse backgrounds, from design to construction. The Hoop House was made of steel conduit and greenhouse heat shrink, and was installed at Phipps Conservatory. We're fortunate that our site was just down the road, about a 5 minute walk through a park.

My role in the project was to analyze the site conditions like the standard sun path, temperature, and humidity using Climate Consultant, as well as making a drone-scanned-style model of the site (I don't have a drone so I cheated a bit and used Google Earth). Relating to the work with sunpath, I made a Grasshopper script that displays the sun path and models surfaces based off those sun angles. As the project developed, I made construction axos and really pushed for expression through joinery, which I see as my largest contribution to the project. I assisted Sean in making full-scale working joinery mock-ups. I also got to play the role of fabricator's advocate. Our group had some fantastic designers and strong wills, and I made that our final design could be fabricated and ideally had some truly beautiful movement and joinery. At the end of the day, we were limited to electrical conduit and greenhouse plastic so there was plenty of opportunities to get creative! One final role I played was that I made a documentation video of our project with my GoPro hung off of a shelf in the ceiling.

For a project with so many moving parts and small openings, it was one of the few that didn't fall apart or tear open when I went back to visit after winter break, and of the other greenhouses that remained intact it also kept about half of the plants alive. By that point, most of the other greenhouses had fallen down or had tears in the greenhouse plastic. The skills I learned working with conduit would be something I'd keep with me, coming into play years later with my Safety Stand project. I think this project alone helped me find my place as someone fascinated with fabrication.
projects.Description: A greenhouse made to weather the Pittsburgh winter

projects.Title: Moorewood Makerspace Renovation
projects.BodyContent:
The Moorewood Makerspace Renovation was a project spearheaded by Joseph Paetz, the president of ANVIL, the CMU maker club. During this time, ANVIL formed a small group of four to come up with ideas to bring to housing. I volunteered as the club's resident architecture student and as someone with a growing passion for makerspaces.

The space that already was underutilized and Housing was going to renovate many of the spaces in the dorm including the makerspace. The spaces were commonly empty even in a dorm with hundreds of undergrads. Even though it was built as part of a dorm, it was difficult to access the space due to its restrictive staffing hours and the limitation that only 1 of the 3 spaces was actively staffed. These spaces would be linked by new doors as part of the renovations. Our goal was to do as much as we could to improve the space. As a group, we succeeded in beautifying the space as well as adding access to a laser cutter and 4 Dremel 3D printers. We also improved the furniture and tool options as well as adding small quality of life improvements such as noise-dampening foam and a suggestion box.

While most of our success is attributed to our group which made sure to meet weekly in the space, I can say that my largest direct involvement was the two hand renders where I imagined what the space could look like based on our proposals and a pinch of fantasy! I was told after the project concluded that housing was especially thankful that they looked hand drawn, specifically their rough nature meant that they were confident that there was still flexibility. If I had ended up doing everything in Rhino with photoreal rendering, they wouldn't have felt there was room to compromise.

While I don't have good photos of the space after the renovations, I do hear that it's one of the premier spaces for textile work on campus and is frequently in use by the Cosplay Club. Carnegie Mellon also has a yearly fashion show called SPIRIT which sees a rush of textile artists to any and all capable spaces, and I knew that before I graduated the Moorewood space was packed before that event.

This project was my first where I got to directly improve a makerspace, and while I didn't directly conduct research I learned a lot along the way. I kept the idea of the rough renders in mind when making proposals at the Innovation Co-Lab makerspace years later, and the knowledge I gained at the Moorewood space directly informed some of my decisions when it came time to revamp the Wilson Lab at Duke. However, this project also came with one other valuable learning opportunity: documentation. I knew I had some images of the project, but I had long since lost access to the project files after graduation, and I didn't have any photos of the space after the really substantial renovations were done, nor could I find more than a few marketing photos from Housing or the Cosplay club. I'm glad I was able to uncover the original renders, but at the end of the day it's hard to prove you did something when you don't have photos. While I can't show the impact I know it had, at least I can show what I contributed!
projects.Description: Renovating a Makerspace in a dorm

Images.Description: A view of the makerspace before substantial renovations.

projects.Title: Medieval Fantasy Contest
projects.BodyContent:
In late 2017 I saw that Sketchfab and Mozilla were doing a design competition, with the theme being "Medieval Fantasy". They wanted the entries to make a scene with a bunch of low poly assets and then have all of those assets be downloadable on Sketchfab, presumably so they could be used my Mozilla for some VR development. While I was almost certainly not going to place as a finalist, all participants would recieve a branded Google Cardboard, and between that and it sounding like a more fun project then my studio work I decided to join!

However, there was one challenge that lay ahead. I was the most experienced in Rhino, and well, that's not a modeling program that's optimized around a low-poly workflow. I did know how to place points though, and I knew how to build surfaces between those points... Basically, I ended up hand placing many of the vertices that I'd later manually paint in with tris. After building out the terrain that way, most of my other props got made with geometric primitives and boolean operations. I did have a great time though, and enjoyed adding tiny details here and there, like the banners having knots in the string or the spears having their heads lashed into notches like arrowheads. I ended up doing versions with blue and red heraldry. There ended up being 48 individual props counting all variations! You can view the results of the competition here!
The Entire Collection

Medieval Fantasy Design Competition Entry by KThies on Sketchfab
projects.Description: Low-poly medieval assets for a Sketchfab Competition

projects.Title: Gray Squirrel Coffee Co
projects.BodyContent:
For two summers I worked with an architect named Matthew Ford who ran Moment Studio. It was a one-man company, and while working with him I got to contribute to a number of buildings in the area, but none would be as impactful as Gray Squirrel.

The coffee company had already worked with Moment Studio in their renovations to install a metal awning and outdoor seating, and when I joined the project we were looking at redoing the hardscaping in front of the building. While Matthew knew a lot about the local code requirements and some of the more mundane aspects of the renovations, he left me with a lot of freedom and trust. I got to pick out lighting fixtures, do the main plan drawing showing all of our desired changes, as well as do renders to really sell the ideas. One area I got to go a little wild with was I got to propose and design a new table that would pivot near the entrance, going so far as to make an animation and BOM. While it ultimately didn't make the cut, many of the other aspects of the plan went through. This was the closest in my career I had gotten to truly feel like I was architecting, and I valued that working with a small firm meant I had a lot of flexibility and room to be creative, even if most of the job was iterating on construction drawings. It helped inform my decision to ultimately not go into the field of architecture.
projects.Description: Renovations of a Coffee Shop in Carrboro

projects.Title: It'd Take a Miracle: Magical Girls at the End of the World
projects.BodyContent:
It'd Take a Miracle, or ITAM, was my first foray into solo game design, and would be the first of my yearly magical girl TTRPGs. Although I had graduated from CMU, I was still an alumnus member and a lot was remote after the pandemic. One initiative I had started during my presidency was the Game Creation Month, where we'd encourage club members to make a small game, adventure, or piece of homebrew. The timeline also coincided with a time loop set within my favorite show, Puella Magi Madoka Magica, so I figured it'd be a fun time to challenge myself.

The restrictions of Game Creation Month was that the creations were to be no more than 50 pages long and the things had to be created entirely within the month of April, so I had some constraints to work with. I also wanted to make sure that most relevant content would be fully contained within a spread or two, so I had to make sure I wouldn't end up with awkward half-pages. The challenge near the end was cutting everything down to hit the 50 page limit! I decided to build a system from scratch, and I unofficially say it's run by the Miracle Engine. One of my early decisions was a dice system that involved rolling 2d6 and adding the values together, but against duplex attributes. That meant that if your Body score was 8, an 8 or below would be counted as a success for a Force roll, but you'd need an 8 or above to succeed on a Speed roll. Additionally, Your rolls could be enhanced or reduced, in which case you'd add an extra d6 to the pool. When Enhanced, you'd choose a die to remove from the pool to determine the outcome, but if the roll was Reduced the Game Master, called the Contractor, would remove a dice. The Contractor had a set of points they could build up by giving the players victories to then spend on making consequences more dire. Combat was straightforward, with the actions largely limited to theater of the mind. Players would either be Near or Far from their target and they could choose from a list of combat actions. While the game itself was simple, I had a few opportunities to run one-shots and a campaign using it, and was exceptionally proud of how it ran. It holds up to this day.

Other than the game design aspect itself, I ended up having plenty of time to work on the formatting, and I got to spend a few days just doing artwork for the covers and character sheet. I think my takeaway was that I work really well under the pressure of a deadline and was able to really thrive with the project. Every now and then I think about making revisions, but then realize that would compromise some of the game's simplicity. One of these days I'll print it out and have it join my TTRPG bookshelf.

You can take a look at ITAM on Itch.io here!
projects.Description: A post-apocalypse Magical Girl TTRPG

Images.Description: The front cover. I built the city from prefabs and rendered it in Rhino before some Photoshop post-processing.
The splash spread right after the cover.

The back cover of the book where you can actually see the three magical girls I modelled.
A look at the itch.io page.

projects.Title: Warded Wishes
projects.BodyContent:
Warded Wishes means a lot to me. Warded Wishes would be the 3rd of my yearly magical girl TTRPGs. I decided that for this one, I'd start up an actual Game Jam on Itch.io for my yearly games, so this would be the first and only submission in the first Countdown to Walpurgisnacht game jam. I don't remember much about the crazy 3 weeks I spent making this game, but I knew that once the haze had cleared and I looked back at it, I had made something special. I didn't use AI. It was 100 pages long. In 3 weeks.

To briefly talk about the system itself, I wanted to make something a little more "tactical", where combat was a focus and took place on a hex grid and positioning would matter. Characters had not just an Archetype, traditional classes like Leader, Defender, and Witch, but they also had a Magical Specialty like Barrier magic or Teleportation. Players would have to balance not just their lives as magical girls, but had an Obligation system where they would have to keep up with academic, social, and work obligations. The game expanded on It'd Take a Miracle's action system with an expansive list of actions with various tags that could be used in different contexts. The game also featured an innovative Fate Pool adapted from Kamigakari where players would have a pool of dice they could use to retcon rolls and spend on magic while introducing a layer of resource management. In short, the game had a lot of systems, all lovingly formatted to make the reading experience pleasant.

I set up some goals at the start, and by the end I had blown past them. Of course, that did come with the cost of working on the game during almost every free waking hour and my sleep schedule did get a bit messed up as a result. I truly believe that I captured lightning in a bottle with this one, and while I can't say what I'll do in my future yearly games, I can say that I plan to spend more time working on this game and building out modules more than I am likely to try and one-up it. I do regret my pace though. I ended up putting it off for a few weeks, which meant that by the time I finally figured out the direction I wanted to take it and the framework I'd use, I only had 3 weeks of my deadline left, which I did use to get the game to a completeish state. That also ended up burning me out afterwards, and while I did have an opportunity to playtest it, it was nowhere near what I needed to make substantial improvements to the game. However, I did go back later on after the game was done and create a google sheets character sheet with automation in lieu of a drafted Rhino sheet, and with the aid of ChatGPT I implemented the dice system in Foundry VTT, enabling easier playtesting in the future.

You can take a look at Warded Wishes on Itch.io here!
projects.Description: My Magnum Opus Magical Girl TTRPG.

projects.Title: This Website
projects.BodyContent: Talk about what I learned making the old portfolio website and how I wanted to restructure it with a more programmatic approach. Also how I built backend tools like the markdown-editor and thought about structuring my images, and is generally more capable as a living webpage that I can continuously edit.

projects.Title: Zenith Larp
projects.BodyContent: Talk about how I didn't make the system, but I did get to add content and runs plot for while. Also talk about how it introduced me to LARP in the first place and maybe how I got to design ARGs and props and costuming with aspects of project planning, meeting with a team and it used one of my hobbies - wandering around campus aimlessly. But yeah I made the advanced book, a bestiary, and our player repository, and remaking the item system.
